bestBHT.bht: When they came to Jesus and saw that he was dead already, they noticed the elements of suffering hastening His death, unknown to the malefactors. It was significant that they did not break His legs, as it demonstrated the reality of His death and served a divine purpose. Jesus died before the robbers, His death coming from a broken heart, and the providence of God ensured that His legs were not broken.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: But when they came to Jesus, and saw that he was dead already—there being in His case elements of suffering, unknown to the malefactors, which might naturally hasten His death, lingering though it always was in such cases, not to speak of His previous sufferings.
They brake not his legs—a fact of vast importance, as showing that the reality of His death was visible to those whose business it was to see to it.
The other divine purpose served by it will appear presently.
Albert Barnes: The death of Jesus was doubtless hastened by the intense agony of the garden, and the special sufferings endured as an atonement for sin on the cross.
Saw by the indications of death on his person, and perhaps by the testimony of the centurion, Matthew 27:54.
The death of Jesus was doubtless hastened by the intense agony of the garden, and the special sufferings endured as an atonement for sin on the cross.
John Calvin: But when they came to Jesus, and saw that he was already dead...appears to be a very extraordinary work of the providence of God.

Ungodly men will, no doubt, say that it happens naturally that one man dies sooner than another; but, if we examine carefully the whole course of the narrative, we shall be constrained to ascribe it to the secret purpose of God.
The death of Christ was brought on much more rapidly than men could have at all expected, and that this prevented his legs from being broken.
Archibald T. Robertson: So then Jesus died before the robbers, died of a broken heart.
John Gill: This they did not out of tenderness to him, but that he might be the longer in his torture, and whom they reserved till last, that they might use him with the greater cruelty and barbarity.
And saw that he was dead already; as they might, from the bowing down of his head, the ghastliness of his countenance, the falling of his jaws, and other signs.
Though the true reason was, and which restrained them from it, divine providence would not suffer them to do it.

bhtAttempts.bht: When they came to Jesus and saw that he was dead already, they noticed the elements of suffering, unknown to the malefactors, which might have hastened His death. It was important that they did not break His legs, as it showed that the reality of His death was visible and that His death served a divine purpose. Jesus died before the robbers, a broken heart being the cause of His death. While some may attribute this to natural causes, a closer examination reveals that it was a work of God's providence.

It was important that they did not break His legs, showing the reality of His death and serving a divine purpose. Jesus died before the robbers, His death brought on rapidly, and it was the providence of God that prevented His legs from being broken. This was not out of tenderness, but to prolong His torture and demonstrate cruelty.
